title: Epic 1: Tailwind CSS Migration
description:
Migrate from monolithic 6,686-line CSS file (plus 1,840 lines across 12 component-specific CSS files) to Tailwind CSS. This blocks all future UI work and affects developer productivity.

**Decision:** Tailwind CSS chosen (see closed ticket 1.1 for rationale).

**Scope:** ~8,526 lines of CSS across 13 files, 85 components affected.

**Phases:**
1. Setup & Foundation (1.2, 1.7, 1.8)
2. Small & Mid-size Components (1.3, 1.9, 1.11, 1.12)
3. Modals & Specialized (1.4, 1.10)
4. Large Components (1.5)
5. Cleanup (1.6)
notes:
## Epic 1 Plan Built Out (2026-02-15)

### Full Scope
- **Total CSS to migrate:** ~8,526 lines across 13 files
- **Total components affected:** 85 .tsx files
- **12 child tickets** covering all migration work

### Execution Order (dependency-driven)

**Phase 1: Foundation (can be parallel)**
- 1.2: Setup Tailwind CSS and configure theme
  
**Phase 2: Structure & Primitives (parallel after 1.2)**
- 1.7: Migrate app layout shell (header, sidebar, canvas, etc.)
- 1.8: Migrate shared UI primitives (buttons, forms, scrollbars)

**Phase 3: Small Components (after 1.2, 1.7, 1.8)**
- 1.3: Migrate small/shared components (~13 components under 120 lines)

**Phase 4: Component CSS Files & Mid-Size (parallel after 1.3)**
- 1.9: Migrate 12 component-specific CSS files (1,840 lines)
- 1.11: Migrate remaining mid-size components (~18 components)
- 1.12: Migrate remaining modals (~7 modals)

**Phase 5: Primary Modals (after 1.3, 1.8)**
- 1.4: Migrate primary modal components (~9 modals)

**Phase 6: Specialized & Large (after 1.4)**
- 1.10: Migrate cut list styles + print stylesheet (~1,100 lines)
- 1.5: Migrate large components (Part, Workspace, ContextMenu, etc.)

**Phase 7: Cleanup (after everything)**
- 1.6: Remove old CSS files, update docs, verify

### Parallelization Opportunities
- 1.7 and 1.8 can run in parallel (both only depend on 1.2)
- 1.9, 1.11, and 1.12 can run in parallel (all depend on 1.3/1.8)
- 1.10 and 1.5 are sequential (1.5 depends on 1.10)

### Estimated Total Effort
~95 hours (based on individual ticket estimates)

title: 1.1: Evaluate CSS approaches (Tailwind vs CSS Modules)
description: Research and decide between Tailwind CSS, CSS Modules, or other approaches. Document pros/cons, migration effort, and team preference. Create ADR (Architecture Decision Record).
notes:
## Decision: Tailwind CSS âœ…

**Decision Date:** 2026-02-14

**Chosen Approach:** Tailwind CSS

**Reasoning:**
1. Solves core problems (scoping, naming, maintainability)
2. Massive productivity gains (2-3x faster styling)
3. Tiny bundle size (only ships used CSS)
4. Perfect for React + TypeScript + Electron
5. Industry standard with huge community
6. Future-proof and well-maintained

**Trade-offs Accepted:**
- Learning curve (2-3 weeks to get comfortable)
- Longer initial migration (3-4 weeks vs 2-3 for CSS Modules)
- Different paradigm (utility-first vs component classes)

**Why Not CSS Modules:**
- Still requires writing CSS files
- Less productive long-term
- No built-in design system

**Next Steps:**
- Create implementation tickets
- Start with setup and configuration
- Migrate incrementally, keeping tests passing

title: Migrate cut list styles and print stylesheet to Tailwind
description:
Migrate the cut list CSS section (~1,100 lines) and print stylesheet to Tailwind. This is the single largest CSS section in the app and includes complex specialized styling.

**CSS Sections to Migrate:**

1. **Cut List Modal (~700 lines)**
   - Tab content header with download dropdown
   - Generate UI (when no cut list exists)
   - Validation issues in generate view
   - Stale warning banner
   - Error/warning banners (skipped parts)
   - Cut List tabs (Parts, Diagrams, Shopping List, Statistics)
   - Parts tab container with scrolling
   - Diagrams tab container (complex grid layout)
   - Stock group and boards grid layout

2. **Cut List Parts Table (~200 lines)**
   - Table with glue-up strips and badges
   - Grouped cut list table styling
   - Grain direction badges

3. **Stock Board Diagrams (~100 lines)**
   - SVG/canvas rendering styles
   - Board visualization

4. **Shopping List Tab (~200 lines)**
   - Overage warnings and totals
   - Shopping list section headers
   - Custom items section and form
   - Subtotal rows

5. **Cut List Statistics (~50 lines)**

6. **Print Stylesheet (~150 lines)**
   - @media print rules for cutting diagrams
   - Page break handling
   - Print-specific layout adjustments
   - Hidden elements during print
   - This is CRITICAL to get right - users print these for the workshop

**Approach:**
- Migrate Cut List Modal structure first
- Then table styling
- Then diagrams
- Then shopping list
- Print styles LAST (test by printing to PDF)
- Test each section thoroughly - this is a revenue-critical feature

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- All cut list styling migrated to Tailwind
- Print stylesheet working correctly (test with Print to PDF)
- All tabs render correctly
- Validation/warning banners display properly
- Shopping list renders correctly
- Statistics render correctly
- All tests passing
- No visual regressions

**Risk: MEDIUM-HIGH**
- Print styles are fragile and hard to test
- Complex grid layouts for board diagrams
- Users rely on printed cut lists in their workshop

title: Migrate app layout shell to Tailwind
description:
Migrate the app layout shell (header, sidebar, toolbar, canvas container, properties panel) to Tailwind CSS. These foundational layout styles form the structure everything else sits within.

**CSS Sections to Migrate (~800 lines in index.css):**
- App layout container (flex grid, main structure)
- macOS traffic light padding
- Windows/Linux window controls overlay
- Header (left section, file menu area, title, header buttons)
- Toolbar
- Sidebar (240px, overflow handling, section content, collapsed sections, search bar)
- Canvas container
- Properties panel
- Section content animation

**Approach:**
- Work from the outermost shell inward
- App.tsx and its immediate children
- Test at each step to ensure layout integrity
- Ensure macOS/Windows platform-specific styles are preserved
- Verify responsive behavior (sidebar collapse, etc.)

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- App layout shell fully using Tailwind classes
- Header, sidebar, toolbar, canvas, properties panel all styled with Tailwind
- Platform-specific styles (macOS, Windows) preserved
- No layout shifts or visual regressions
- All tests passing

**Why this ticket exists:**
Layout styles are foundational - nearly every component renders inside this shell. Migrating layout first means component migrations can rely on Tailwind layout utilities being in place.

title: Migrate shared UI primitives to Tailwind (buttons, forms, scrollbars)
description:
Migrate shared UI primitive systems to Tailwind CSS. These primitives are used across dozens of components, so migrating them early establishes patterns and reduces work in later tickets.

**1. Button System (~250 lines in index.css)**
- 5 size variants: btn-xs, btn-sm, btn-md, btn-lg, plus icon buttons (btn-icon-xs, btn-icon-sm, btn-icon-md)
- 3 style types: Filled, Outlined, Ghost
- 3 color variants: Primary (accent), Secondary (neutral), Danger (destructive)
- Modifiers: Full width, active toggle state, button groups
- Accessibility: Focus-visible states for keyboard navigation
- Consider creating a Tailwind component class or utility pattern

**2. Form Elements (~200 lines)**
- Labels with checkboxes
- Input fields and textareas
- Checkbox styling (custom appearance)
- Radio button styling
- Settings rows with help text
- Input with suffix (e.g., percentage fields)
- Disabled states

**3. Custom Scrollbars (~50 lines)**
- WebKit scrollbar styling
- Firefox scrollbar styling

**4. Miscellaneous Shared Patterns (~100 lines)**
- Help tooltip pattern
- Label with help icon pattern
- Hotkey hints bar
- Dropdown button
- Grain direction selector

**Approach:**
- Create Tailwind @apply-based component classes for buttons (or use @layer components)
- Document the button variant system in STYLING.md
- Migrate form elements to Tailwind utility classes
- Test thoroughly - these patterns are used everywhere

**Acceptance Criteria:**
- Button system fully using Tailwind (all variants working)
- Form elements migrated to Tailwind
- Custom scrollbars working
- Shared patterns migrated
- All components using these primitives still render correctly
- All tests passing
- Patterns documented in STYLING.md

**Note:** This ticket overlaps slightly with Epic 2 ticket 2.10 (Extract common Button patterns) and 2.11 (Extract common Form components). Coordinate: this ticket handles the CSS migration, while those tickets handle the component extraction.

title: Epic 3: State Management Split
description: Split the 2,663-line god object store (projectStore.ts) into 7-8 focused stores (UI, camera, selection, snap, etc.). Improves performance and maintainability.

title: 3.1: Design store split architecture
description: Design how to split projectStore into: projectStore (domain data), uiStore (modals/toast), cameraStore (viewport), selectionStore (selected items), snapStore (snap system), assemblyEditingStore (edit mode), licenseStore (feature limits). Document data flow and inter-store communication.
notes:
## Decision: Store Split Architecture Approved âœ…

**Decision Date:** 2026-02-14

**Approved Architecture:**

Split projectStore.ts (2,663 lines) into 7-8 focused stores:

1. **projectStore** (500-800 lines) - Core domain data
   - parts, stocks, groups, assemblies
   - snapGuides, cutList
   - project metadata (name, filePath, isDirty)
   - project settings (units, gridSize, kerf, overage)
   - stockConstraints, customShoppingItems

2. **uiStore** (200-300 lines) - UI/modal state
   - contextMenu, toast
   - pendingDeletePartIds
   - cutListModalOpen, saveAssemblyModalOpen
   - manualThumbnail

3. **cameraStore** (200-300 lines) - Camera/viewport
   - cameraState, cameraViewVectors
   - centerCameraRequested, centerCameraAtOriginRequested
   - displayMode, showGrid, showGrainDirection

4. **selectionStore** (300-400 lines) - Selection state
   - selectedPartIds, selectedGroupIds
   - hoveredPartId
   - transformMode
   - activeDragDelta
   - selectionBox
   - expandedGroupIds

5. **snapStore** (200-300 lines) - Snap system
   - snapToPartsEnabled
   - activeSnapLines
   - referencePartIds
   - activeReferenceDistances

6. **assemblyEditingStore** (200-300 lines) - Assembly editing
   - isEditingAssembly
   - editingAssemblyId
   - editingAssemblyName
   - previousProjectSnapshot

7. **clipboardStore** (100-150 lines) - Copy/paste
   - clipboard.parts
   - clipboard.groups

8. **licenseStore** (100-150 lines) - License/limits
   - licenseMode
   - feature limit checks

**Migration Strategy:**
- Extract stores incrementally
- Start with least-coupled (uiStore, cameraStore)
- Keep tests passing throughout
- Only projectStore persisted to file (others transient)

**Next Steps:**
- Create implementation tickets
- Start with UI and camera stores (lowest risk)
